children.value: In finite field operations, we frequently need to perform mod N calculations. For exponential operations involving consecutive multiplications, Montgomery Reduction provides better performance optimization.
The core idea of Montgomery Reduction is to convert operands to a special Montgomery Form, where all division operations can be significantly simplified.
Let’s understand this through a concrete example:
Given modulus N = 97, we need to calculate

children.html: (a⋅b) mod N(a \cdot b) \bmod N(a⋅b)modN

children.value: . The traditional method requires performing a modular operation on the result of

children.html: a⋅ba \cdot ba⋅b

children.value: Choose R = 100 (usually selected as a power of 2; for demonstration purposes we use 100, which allows us to simply take the last digits or remove trailing zeros in base 10)

children.html: Ta=aR mod N=45T_a = aR \bmod N = 45Ta​=aRmodN=45
Tb=bR mod N=96T_b = bR \bmod N = 96Tb​=bRmodN=96

children.value: Calculate the product in Montgomery Form:

children.html: Tr=Ta⋅Tb=45⋅96=4320T_r = T_a \cdot T_b = 45 \cdot 96 = 4320Tr​=Ta​⋅Tb​=45⋅96=4320

children.value: Since we’ve gone through two Montgomery Form conversions, the result contains an

children.html: R2R^2R2

children.value: term, and we need to eliminate one

children.html: RRR

aR⋅bR/RaR \cdot bR/RaR⋅bR/R
m=Tr⋅N′ mod R=4320⋅67 mod 100=289440 mod 100=40m = T_r \cdot N' \bmod R = 4320 \cdot 67 \bmod 100 = 289440 \bmod 100 = 40m=Tr​⋅N′modR=4320⋅67mod100=289440mod100=40

children.value: (Note: mod 100 in base 10 means taking the last two digits)

children.html: t=(Tr+m⋅N)/R=(4320+40⋅97)/100=8200/100=82=abRt = (T_r + m \cdot N) / R = (4320 + 40 \cdot 97) / 100 = 8200 / 100 = 82 = abRt=(Tr​+m⋅N)/R=(4320+40⋅97)/100=8200/100=82=abR

children.value: (Note: dividing by 100 in base 10 means removing trailing zeros)

children.html: abR/RabR/RabR/R
m′=t⋅N′ mod R=82⋅67 mod 100=94m' = t \cdot N' \bmod R = 82 \cdot 67 \bmod 100 = 94m′=t⋅N′modR=82⋅67mod100=94
t′=(t+m′⋅N)/R=(82+94⋅97)/100=92=abt' = (t + m' \cdot N) / R = (82 + 94 \cdot 97) / 100 = 92 = abt′=(t+m′⋅N)/R=(82+94⋅97)/100=92=ab

children.value: Although Montgomery Reduction may not save much computational resources for a single operation (conversion to Montgomery Form still requires mod N operations), its advantages become very clear in scenarios requiring continuous modular multiplication (such as modular exponentiation):

children.html: a5 mod Na^5 \bmod Na5modN

children.value: Traditional method requires mod N operation after each multiplication

children.html: Ta=aR mod NT_a = aR \bmod NTa​=aRmodN

children.value: No division needed for intermediate operations:
T_a \cdot T_a / R = (aR \cdot aR) / R = a^2R
children.html: Ta⋅Ta/R=(aR⋅aR)/R=a2RT_a \cdot T_a / R = (aR \cdot aR) / R = a^2RTa​⋅Ta​/R=(aR⋅aR)/R=a2R

children.value: Only need to convert back to original form at the end
Avoids mod N operations in intermediate steps
Suitable for hardware implementation (when R is chosen as a power of 2, division and modulo can be completed using shift and bitwise AND operations)
Especially suitable for scenarios requiring continuous modular multiplications
In practical engineering, we typically encode an element a into Montgomery Form by multiplying it by

children.html: R2R^2R2

children.value: . The advantages of this approach are:
Montgomery Reduction and multiplication can be merged into a unified mul function:

children.html: mul(a,b)=ab/R\text{mul}(a, b) = ab/Rmul(a,b)=ab/R

children.value: Both encode and decode can use the same mul function:

children.html: encode(a)=mul(a,R2)=aR2/R=aR\text{encode}(a) = \text{mul}(a, R^2) = aR^2/R = aRencode(a)=mul(a,R2)=aR2/R=aR
decode(Ta)=mul(Ta,1)=aR/R=a\text{decode}(T_a) = \text{mul}(T_a, 1) = aR/R = adecode(Ta​)=mul(Ta​,1)=aR/R=a

children.value: This unified implementation makes the code more concise, and when R is chosen as a power of 2, all division and modulo operations can be efficiently performed through shift and bitwise AND operations.
For modular exponentiation, we can see the advantages of Montgomery multiplication:
a^5 = ((((a \cdot a) \bmod N) \cdot a) \bmod N) \cdot a) \bmod N) \cdot a) \bmod N
children.html: a5=((((a⋅a) mod N)⋅a) mod N)⋅a) mod N)⋅a) mod Na^5 = ((((a \cdot a) \bmod N) \cdot a) \bmod N) \cdot a) \bmod N) \cdot a) \bmod Na5=((((a⋅a)modN)⋅a)modN)⋅a)modN)⋅a)modN

children.value: Each step requires expensive division operations for modular reduction

children.html: Ta=aR mod NT_a = aR \bmod NTa​=aRmodN
Ta⋅Ta/R=a2RT_a \cdot T_a / R = a^2RTa​⋅Ta​/R=a2R
(a2R⋅aR)/R=a3R(a^2R \cdot aR) / R = a^3R(a2R⋅aR)/R=a3R
(a3R⋅aR)/R=a4R(a^3R \cdot aR) / R = a^4R(a3R⋅aR)/R=a4R
(a4R⋅aR)/R=a5R(a^4R \cdot aR) / R = a^5R(a4R⋅aR)/R=a5R
decode(a5R)=a5\text{decode}(a^5R) = a^5decode(a5R)=a5

children.value: All intermediate steps only require simple shift operations, greatly improving performance.
